feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
In a recent discussion within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, concerns were raised about the potential legal implications for developers who implement code changes that could lead to fund confiscation. The apprehension revolves around whether developers might be held legally responsible for any financial losses incurred due to such changes, especially in scenarios where a "bonded courier" surfaces with a private key that could have accessed funds under previous security measures. This topic was highlighted by Jameson Lopp and echoed by Peter Todd in a separate thread, which can be explored further [here](https://groups.google.com/g/bitcoindev/c/bmV1QwYEN4k/m/kkHQZd_BAwAJ).
The discourse also touched upon a philosophical concept referred to as "ethical impedance-mismatch," drawing parallels from its origin in physics and computing. This notion encapsulates the moral and ethical dilemmas faced by those wishing to optimize Bitcoin's functionality while contending with the underlying principle of censorship-resistance. Efforts to filter transactions at the peer-to-peer level, for instance, are seen as fundamentally at odds with Bitcoin's core ethos of resisting censorship, leading to technical shortcomings and inaccuracies in fee rate calculations.
Furthermore, the conversation delved into the broader ramifications of compromising on Bitcoin's foundational promise of censorship-resistance. It was argued that any attempt by developers to facilitate fund confiscation or similar actions would not only violate this promise but also invite external interference from political and legal entities aiming to exploit such vulnerabilities for their own ends. The term "quantum recovery" was introduced in this context, suggesting a need for Bitcoin to maintain its capacity for recovery outside of any centralized control. The discussion concluded on a note of caution against any form of confiscation within Bitcoin, positing that the currency's survival hinges on its ability to uphold its defining principles, even in the face of unforeseen challenges that may arise in the future.
